Consider the second-order logic formula:

$$\varphi(x) := \forall P(\forall Q((P(0) \land \forall x (P(x) \rightarrow P(x+1))) \rightarrow Q) \rightarrow P(x))$$

where $P$ and $Q$ are unary predicates over the natural numbers. 

If we interpret $P$ and $Q$ as the properties of being prime or composite, respectively, prove that $x$ cannot be prime and composite at the same time in second-order logic.
message_2:
To prove that $x$ cannot be prime and composite at the same time, we will show that the properties of being prime and composite are mutually exclusive. In other words, if $x$ is prime, it cannot be composite, and if $x$ is composite, it cannot be prime.

Let $P(x)$ denote the property of being prime and $Q(x)$ denote the property of being composite. Recall the definitions of prime and composite numbers:

1. A prime number is a natural number greater than 1 that has exactly two distinct positive divisors: 1 and itself.
2. A composite number is a natural number greater than 1 that has more than two distinct positive divisors.

Now, let's assume for contradiction that there exists a natural number $x$ such that it is both prime and composite. That is, $P(x) \land Q(x)$ holds.

Since $x$ is prime, it has exactly two distinct positive divisors: 1 and $x$. However, since $x$ is also composite, it has more than two distinct positive divisors. This is a contradiction, as a number cannot have both exactly two divisors and more than two divisors at the same time.

Therefore, our assumption that there exists a natural number $x$ such that it is both prime and composite is false. In second-order logic, this can be expressed as:

$$\forall x (\neg (P(x) \land Q(x)))$$

This statement asserts that for all natural numbers $x$, $x$ cannot be both prime and composite at the same time.
